Chapter 9, Part 1: Distinguishing and Ascertaining, Distinguishing and Ascertaining the First of Nine Parts. Thus far, the distinctions of various knowledges have been discussed. Next, we will distinguish the samÄdhis that are the bases of knowledge.
Only the various dhyÄnas can fully serve as bases, so they are first distinguished here.

What are the dhyÄnas among the various samÄdhis?
Verse:
The dhyÄnas are four each with two, the arising within them has been explained.
SamÄdhi is of good and single-pointedness, with the nature of five aggregates along with its associates.

The treatise says:
Since all merits mostly rely on dhyÄna, we should first distinguish the differences in dhyÄna.
In general there are four kinds, called the first, second, third, and fourth.

Are there no names and concepts of the dharmas of the immeasurables, such as loving kindness, that are unique to the trances, and are the names of the first, second, etc., established on the basis of number alone?

There are not no names and concepts that are unique to the trances, but there are none that are found in all stages. Each trance is of two kinds, because there is a distinction between samÄdhi and birth.
The trances of birth have already been discussed above, i.e., the fourth is eight, the first two are two, and the rest are three.
There is no other name that generally signifies one stage.

The general characteristics of the samÄdhis of the trances are not different, because in general they are all categorized as the nature of good, i.e., one-pointedness of mind, because their intrinsic nature is that of good samÄdhi.
If they are accompanied by their adjutants, their nature is that of the five aggregates.
Since these two are the same, it is difficult to know their difference.

Although their characteristics are not different, their stages are different. In order to reveal the difference in stages, they are named according to number, and therefore they are called the first, up to the fourth.
Here the author of the ÅšÄstra himself raises a question and answers it: What is meant by â€œone-pointedness of mindâ€?
It means being concentrated on a single object.
His answer is unreasonable, because if the two consciousnesses of eye and manas have the same object, they should be called one-pointedness of mind.
Therefore, we must seek another explanation here.

If it is said that being concentrated on a single object by depending on a single organ is called one-pointedness of mind, then would it not be the case that in a single moment there is no change in the object and that therefore all minds would be one-pointed?
In reality, all minds are one-pointed, because in each moment of mind and mental activities, they evolve with a single object, but not all are called samÄdhi.
Because in this context, one-pointedness of mind is explained as being a continuity of good mind and mental activities brought about by the power of superior samÄdhi.

If this is so, then mind evolves by depending on a single organ, and other minds continue in succession, attracted by the mind that takes its own object. This is called one-pointedness of mind, and there should be no samÄdhi apart from mind.
This objection is not valid, because it has already been explained.
In the chapter on mental activities, we have already explained that samÄdhi is a separate dharma apart from mind.

If the essence of mind is samÄdhi, then that which causes the mind to be even would also not be separate, because we cannot find a cause of distinction. Such difficulties are fully explained above. Therefore samÄdhi is not the same as mind.
In what sense is samÄdhi called LIBERATION?
Liberation is so called because one is able to contemplate things well by relying on this samÄdhi.

To contemplate well is the meaning of to understand things as they really are. It is said that mind in samÄdhi is able to understand things as they really are. The meaning of contemplation is to place the mind in samÄdhi.
The principle of this treatise is that samÄdhi is by nature discernment.

According to the principle of etymological analysis, it is a place where the mind is calm and contemplates objects, and for that reason it is called LIBERATION, because samÄdhi causes discernment to be born free from turbidity and confusion.
There is an opinion that this samÄdhi is called LIBERATION because it holds the superior and universal contemplation of objects in accordance with reality.
The word superior excludes the desire realm, universal excludes the formless realm, and contemplation in accordance with reality excludes the distorted. It is able to hold.
This samÄdhi is a wondrous samÄdhi, and this wondrous samÄdhi is called dhyÄna.
This statement shows that the practice of Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ in equal measure, and the samÄdhi that is free from error, is called dhyÄna.
If that is so, how can the defiled [samÄdhi] obtain this name?
Because it can also wrongly investigate, it is given this name in a similar case. It is like the worldly saying rotten seeds, etc. Therefore there is no error in calling all [samÄdhis] dhyÄna.

If the one-pointedness of mind that is of the nature of wholesome [dharmas] and its accompaniments are established as the four dhyÄnas, on what characteristics are the first, second, third, and fourth [dhyÄnas] established?
[The first dhyÄna] is established as being endowed with investigation, joy, and pleasure.
That is to say, in that state, the one-pointedness of mind that is wholesome is endowed with investigation, discursive thought, joy, and pleasure. Such a samÄdhi is called the first dhyÄna.
In the verse, it only says it is endowed with investigation, but it has already shown that it is also endowed with discursive thought.
Because if it has investigation and is accompanied by joy and pleasure, it must also be accompanied by discursive thought.
In order to show the second division, which is established by excluding applied thought, the verse only says that it is associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought.
If it were otherwise, it should say that it is associated with applied thought, joy, and pleasure. The existence of applied thought and sustained thought is self-evident.

The second and third divisions are established by gradually eliminating the first two branches. The second division is associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought. The third division is associated with joy and pleasure but not with sustained thought. The fourth division is completely devoid of the first three. Thus one-pointedness of mind is divided into four kinds.
The dhyÄnas have been discussed.
What are the formless realms?
The verse states:
The formless realms are also like this, with four aggregates, free from the lower realms,
And the three upper preliminary concentrations, collectively called the elimination of the notion of form.
The formless realms are called formless because they lack form, and form arises from the mind.
The three formless realms beginning with infinite space are named according to their preparatory practices.
The name of neither perception nor non-perception is established because it is dull and inferior.
The treatise states:
The formless realms are the same in number as the dhyÄnas, with four each having two kinds.
Birth is as explained above, that is, in the chapter on the world, where it is said that there are four kinds of birth.
The substance of the formless concentrations is, in general, also the one-pointedness of mind that is good in nature.
On the basis of this, the text says, â€œIt is the same.â€
However, in the group of accompanying dharmas, form is excluded, because there is no derivative form in the formless realms.

Although one-pointedness of mind and its accompanying dharmas are not different, they are divided into four kinds because one is born in the upper stages and is separated from the lower stages. That is, the concentration of the sphere of infinite space is established when one is separated from birth in the fourth trance state, and so on, up to the concentration of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization, which is established when one is separated from birth in the sphere of nothingness.
What is the meaning of the term separation ?
It means that by this path one is liberated from the passions of the lower stage. This is the meaning of separation from the impurity of the lower stage.
These four fundamental concentrations and the three intermediate concentrations are generally referred to as the elimination of the notion of form.

The preliminary concentration of the sphere of infinite space has not yet attained this name, because it generates the notion of form of the lower stage. The name elimination of the notion of form cannot be established on the basis of the notion of form of the lower stage.
If this is so, why does the Abhidharmasamuccaya say that the removal of the notion of form is the fourth trance state?
It is because one gradually removes the notion of form that exists in oneâ€™s own body in the desire realm. This notion cannot exist in the formless realm.
It is also not a mistake to call the fundamental trance state the removal of the notion of form, because it is the preliminary practice for the removal of the notion of form.
In virtue of what meaning is the name formless received?
It is because there is absolutely no form in virtue of that.
When one dies in the formless realm and is reborn in a lower realm, form is born from mind. We see in the world that non-form is born from form.
There is also a mutual dependence of form and non-form, because when mind is different, differences in form are born, and when the sense organs are different, consciousness is born differently.

Therefore, when one is about to be born in a lower realm from the formless realm, a mental series that is favorable to the birth of form exists, and by the power of that, form is attracted and born in a lower realm.
However, it cannot be said that it is born from that alone.

Also, the mind associated with form in a previous life is the condition for the subsequent mind, and the form that has long since ceased is the seed of the present form. It is admitted that homogeneous causes extend to the past and present.

When arhats enter parinirvÄá¹‡a, the continuity of their aggregates is completely severed. Therefore, there is no present condition for the arising of any part of the aggregates. This cannot be compared to the case of death from the formless realm.
This is the explanation of the general name for the formless realm.

The first three are named according to the preparatory stage, because in the stage of preparatory practice one contemplates infinite space, infinite consciousness, and nothingness.
If one accomplishes the preparatory practice of contemplating infinite space by means of superior resolve, it is named Ä€kÄÅ›ÄnantyÄyatana, the sphere of infinite space.
That is, although this dharma is associated with form, its own substance is not dependent on form.
Those who seek liberation from form must first contemplate this dharma.
That is, although the substance of space is associated with form, it is only manifested by the absence of form.
The characteristics of external objects are limitless, and when one contemplates them, it is easy to be free of form. Therefore, in the stage of added effort, one contemplates space.
When it is accomplished, one may also contemplate other dharmas as appropriate. However, this name is established according to the added effort.
If, by means of resolve, one contemplates limitless consciousness, it is accomplished by added effort and is called the sphere of limitless consciousness.

That is, in the six pure sense consciousnesses that are able to discriminate, one grasps the characteristics well, abides in resolve, and by the power of imagination contemplates the characteristics of limitless consciousness.
By this added effort, one may also contemplate other dharmas as appropriate. However, this name is established according to the added effort.
If, by means of resolve, one abandons all possessions, it is accomplished by added effort and is called the sphere of nothingness.

That is, one sees the characteristics of limitless consciousness as coarse and agitated, and in order to be disgusted with and abandon them, one gives rise to this added effort. Therefore, this sphere is called supreme abandonment.
Because in this stage one no longer delights in the sign of infinity, and the mind, in regard to the object, abandons all signs and abides in tranquil extinction.

The fourth stage is so called because conceptualization is dull and weak, that is, because conceptualization is not clear and superior in this stage, as in the state of nonconceptualization. It is called nonconceptualization,
but because conceptualization is not totally absent, it is called neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization.
This stage is so called because it still has dull and weak conceptualization.
This statement shows that conceptualization in the stage of the peak of existence is not like that of the lower seven stages, and thus it is called nonconceptualization.
It is not like the three mindless stages, and thus it is called neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization.
Isnâ€™t it the case that in the path of added effort of the peak of existence, yogis also think,

Conceptualization is like a disease, like an arrow, like a boil. In the mindless heaven of nonconceptualization, it is like stupidity and darkness. There is only the heaven of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization, which is contrary to the above and is tranquil and wonderful.
Why not establish the name on the basis of the path of added effort?
This is indeed reasonable, because the contemplator must first be disgusted with conceptualization and nonconceptualization.
However, there may be a question:
Why does the practitioner, when cultivating the preparatory practices, have such thoughts?
It must be raised as the cause for answering the question, therefore it is said that the names are established due to the dullness of conceptualization.
As for these four formless [absorptions] all being called places, it is because they are the places where various existences grow.

That is to say, these four places are the places where various existences grow due to the various karmas and afflictions. In order to destroy the false conception that they are nirvÄá¹‡a, the Buddha taught them to be the places where existences grow.
The formless [absorptions] have already been explained.
What are the meditative attainments?
In verse it is said:ğŸ”½These fundamental meditative attainments are eight,
The first seven each have three,ğŸ”½Namely, those with relishing, pure, and uncontaminated,
The last two are of relishing and pure.
Those with relishing are associated with craving, pure refers to worldly goodness,
These are precisely what is relished, uncontaminated refers to supramundane.
In the treatise it is said:

The fundamental samÄdhis of the dhyÄnas and formless concentrations are of eight kinds. The first seven each have three kinds. The samÄdhi of the peak of existence is of only two kinds, because this stage is dull and inferior, is the root of birth and death, is at the extreme of the stages, and is devoid of pure dhyÄna.

The first is the samÄdhi of enjoyment, which is associated with craving. Craving is called enjoyment because it is able to enjoy the object. It is called enjoyment samÄdhi because it is associated with craving.
The words associated with craving are stated from the point of view of intrinsic substance, because this samÄdhi has samÄdhi as its intrinsic nature.
If we add its auxiliaries, we should say
that the class of dharmas associated with craving is called the samÄdhi of enjoyment.
This means that it takes only the class of dharmas that is the single effect of craving.
The samÄdhi of purity is called pure good samÄdhi, because it is free from the defilement of passions, and because it is associated with pure dharmas such as absence of greed.
It is different from the samÄdhi of enjoyment because it is good, and it is different from the pure samÄdhi because it is impure.
It is the object of enjoyment of the previous samÄdhi of enjoyment, and the samÄdhi of enjoyment is born immediately after it.
When one deeply relishes the purity of the past, at that time although it is said that one emerges from the samÄdhi of relishing, with regard to the samÄdhi of relishing, it is called entering.
There are five kinds of emerging from samÄdhi:
1. emerging from the stage, 2. emerging from the moment, 3. emerging from the aspect of practice, 4. emerging from the object, and 5. emerging from the type.
Entering the second dhyÄna and so on from the first dhyÄna is called emerging from the stage.
In the state of continuation of the same stage, aspect, and object, the previous moment enters the subsequent moment without interval, which is called emerging from the moment.
Entering the aspect of suffering from the aspect of impermanence and so on is called emerging from the aspect of practice.
Entering the feeling aggregate and so on from the form aggregate and so on as the object is called emerging from the object.
Emerging from the defiled from the undefiled, and so on, is called emerging from the type.
Based on emerging from the type, it is said here that one emerges from the relished and enters the relishing samÄdhi. Aren't these two statements contradictory?

The object of entry is concentration, and is not called â€œthat which tastes.â€
How can it be said that entry is concentration that tastes?
There is no contradiction, because it is seen that in the case of association, one member of the pair is mentioned.
For example, when one is exhorted to make a gift, one remembers the giver and the recipient, and vice versa. Because they are mixed, each is said to possess both names.

Because of association with craving, concentration is called â€œthat which tastes,â€ and because of the power of concentration, craving is called â€œconcentration.â€ Therefore there is no contradiction in speaking of both.

There is an opinion that concentration and craving appear in a series, and later moments take as objects earlier moments. That which is tasted is the moment that has just ceased, and that which tastes is the moment that has just been born.

When the craving that tastes appears in the present, it takes as its object a past object, not a present one, nor does it take as its object its own nature, associated dharmas, or those dharmas that are its concomitants, because it does not necessarily consider its own nature, etc.
It does not take the future as an object, because it has not been experienced.
Only that which is called concentration can focus on an object and not shift.
Concentration associated with craving is also focused on a single object and therefore can be called concentration. This is not the case for concentration associated with other passions.

That is, other passions are not able to cause the mind to be focused on its object to the same degree as craving. Therefore, when samÄdhi is associated with craving, it is focused on a single object and resembles the good variety.
Pure concentration is supramundane concentration, because craving does not take it as an object and it is not relished.
Of the above-mentioned eight kinds of samÄdhi, only the dhyÄnas possess members, not the formless realms, because the formless realms are extremely tranquil.

That is, the ascetic who delights in cultivating the good dharmas, if he establishes members in the vast aggregate of merit and diligently cultivates them, but if the mind and mental activities of the formless realms are dull and weak because of the increase of tranquility, then the members are not established there.
Or, it is said that samÄdhi is predominant in those stages, but one predominant dharma cannot be called a member. Only when there is an increase of many dharmas can they be called members.
Therefore only this meditation is established as having members, because the practice of samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä increases many dharmas.
Therefore the preliminary concentration is also not established as having members, because in the preliminary concentration of form, only prajÃ±Ä increases.
Other masters say:
If there are other mental activities in the various stages, and if they are completely eliminated, only then are they established as members of this stage, not the others.

In the first meditation, sorrow and suffering are eliminated. In the second meditation, initial and sustained thought are completely eliminated. In the third, joy is eliminated. In the fourth, pleasure is eliminated. Although in the formless stages they are gradually reduced, there is no complete elimination in each stage.
This explanation still fails to resolve the questioner's doubt. What is the reason that only these are established as members?
Therefore the previous explanation is correct.
How many members are there in the four meditations?
Verse:
The first meditation has five members: initial thought, sustained thought, joy, pleasure, and samÄdhi.
The second has four members: internal purity, joy, pleasure, and samÄdhi.
The third has five branches: equanimity, mindfulness, wisdom, pleasure, and samÄdhi.
The fourth has four branches: equanimity, mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain, and samÄdhi.
The treatise says:
Only the pure and uncontaminated four dhyÄnas have five branches in the first: investigation, analysis, joy, pleasure, and one-pointedness of mind.

One-pointedness of mind is a synonym for samÄdhi. SamÄdhi and samÄhita have the same substance but different names. Therefore, samÄdhi is said to be the superior samÄhita, which is called one-pointedness of mind here.
The second dhyÄna has only four branches: internal purity, joy, pleasure, and one-pointedness of mind.
The third dhyÄna has five branches: equanimity, right mindfulness, right wisdom, the feeling of pleasure, and one-pointedness of mind.
The fourth dhyÄna has only four branches: the purity of equanimity, the purity of mindfulness, the feeling that is neither pleasure nor pain, and one-pointedness of mind.
Why are the first three each composed of five members, and the second and fourth each only of four members?
Because each is only that many in number and is able to be established as a member.
Or, because the realm of desire is replete with many evil dharmas and with the five desires that are difficult to cut off and abandon.

The second trance state has the agitation of joy, whose characteristics are agitation and surging, and it is the extreme of joy. It attracts the five classes of thirst that are difficult to abandon and difficult to cut off.
In order to counteract them, the first three each have five members.
The second and fourth are not like the first three, and therefore the remaining two each have only four members.

Or, in order to conform to the method of supernormal spiritual powers, that is, when one first produces supernormal spiritual powers, it is difficult to enter into different categories, but easy to enter into the same category.

However, when one first produces supernormal spiritual powers, one may enter the third from the first, or the fourth from the second. Therefore the second and fourth each have only four members, and the first and third each have all five.
When one produces them later, it is easy, and therefore there are no members above.
Since the names of the members of the trances are eighteen in number, how many of these are actually real dharmas?
The verse says:
In reality there are eleven factors. The first two are joy and pleasure.
Inner purity is the faculty of faith, and joy is the feeling of joy.
The treatise says:
In reality there are only eleven factors. The first five factors are five real entities.
The second dhyÄna has three factors as before, and adding the factor of inner purity makes six.
The third dhyÄna has the samÄdhi as before, and adding the remaining four factors makes ten.
The fourth dhyÄna has three factors as before, and adding the factor of neither-pleasure-nor-discomfort makes eleven.
Why are mind and so on not factors of dhyÄna?
This should be distinguished according to the factors of enlightenment discussed previously.
Those that differ from that will now be briefly distinguished.
Among the feelings, three are established but not sorrow and discomfort, because sorrow and discomfort are only included in the desire realm.
The three feelings according to the ground are factors of benefit, because their function in accordance with samÄdhi is strong, and therefore they are all included as factors.

The members of the various meditations are favorable to the superior stage, and vigor is favorable to the superior stage, and therefore it is not established as a member.
Or, the members of the meditations are the ease of the division of comfort, and vigor is the painful exertion of seeking the superior.

The two, applied thought and sustained thought, are able to assist samÄdhi, control the mind, and cause it to be free from grossness and subtlety, and they are established as members because they are the antidote to desire and evil.
Why is the noninformative not a member of the meditations?
The members of the meditations assist samÄdhi in abiding in the object, but it does not take the object as object, and therefore it is not established as a member.

Therefore, although there are eighteen members of the meditations, they are distinguished according to the various stages, but if we seek them in the actual entities and kinds, there are only nine kinds. However, they are divided into eleven because feeling and conceptualization are different.
Consequently, it is said that there is a first member that does not exist as a second member.
We should make four alternatives.
The first alternative is applied thought and sustained thought.
The second alternative is internal purity.
The third alternative is joy, pleasure, and samÄdhi.
The fourth alternative is the exception of the above and the rest of the dharmas.
The remaining members should be considered in the same way.
What is the meaning of the term â€œmemberâ€ (Äá¹…ga) here?
It means to manifest and accomplish.
What is accomplished?
It means to manifest and accomplish this is the first trance state, up to this is the fourth trance state.
Or, the term â€œmemberâ€ means to follow the meaning, like the name â€œother membersâ€ (Äá¹…ga) such as the jujube tree, which means the eighteen members each follow their own stage.

Or, the meaning of â€œprovisionâ€ is called a member, like the members of a sacrifice which are cattle, horses, etc., which means that applied thought, sustained thought, etc. mutually assist each other.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters manifest the most excellent samÄdhi in the stages of trance, therefore they say this.
SamÄdhi is both trance and a member of trance.
Applied thought, sustained thought, etc. are members of trance but not trance.

Because a sÅ«tra says:

However, the meaning of the two is similar in that they are mutually supportive and protective, just as an army with four divisions is not defective. Just as a king and his army mutually support each other, yet the king is the most important.
Isnâ€™t the substance of pleasure in the three trance states the same? Then the members of trance should not be eleven.
The substance of pleasure in the third trance state is feeling, and pleasure in the first two trances is serenity. Therefore the members of trance are really eleven.
Serenity and equanimity are found in all four trances. For what reason are only the first two called serenity, and the last two called equanimity?
Because they are in accordance with the first two and the last two.
In the realm of desire there are many evil dharmas. In the first trance state there is the conceptualization of applied and sustained thought that can oppress the mind, just as a poisoned arrow does.
The first two are free from these, and therefore serenity increases.

In the second trance state, joy is extreme and agitates the mind. In the third trance state, the feeling of pleasure is extreme. Both are able to be the excellent place of birth for craving. The fourth and fifth abandon them, and therefore the practice of equanimity increases.

Or, in the desire realm and the first trance state, the coarseness and heaviness induced by the material faculties and consciousness is worse than in other stages. The first two trance states are free from that, and therefore pliancy increases.
In the fourth and fifth stages, one is far from coarseness and heaviness, and the tranquility is increasingly excellent, and therefore the practice of equanimity increases.

That is to say, pliancy and pleasure are like first putting down a burden. If one changes to another stage, the energy and constitution are slightly thin, and therefore only the first two establish pliancy.
In the fourth and fifth stages, one proceeds spontaneously, and the tranquility is increasingly excellent, and therefore one establishes the practice of equanimity.
Or, in the first two trance states, there are conditions for pliancy, because joy is the excellent condition for pliancy.
As a scripture says:
Because of joy, there is pliancy.
In the fourth and fifth trance states, there is no condition for joy, and therefore pliancy is slight and not established as a member.
The practice of equanimity and pliancy mutually conceal each other. If one exists in a place, the second is absent.

Lightness and serenity cure sinking, and their characteristics are floating and lofty. Equanimity cures agitation, and its characteristic is calm cessation. Therefore, serenity and equanimity mutually conceal each other.
What principle is there to prove that the three members of pleasure are lightness and serenity, and the third is feeling?
It has already been said that they are biased in accordance with it.
That is, the pleasure of the third trance state is not lightness and serenity, and serenity is not its member.
Next, it has already been said that the pleasure of the first two trances is definitely not pleasant feeling. It is feeling of body and mind together, because it is not reasonable otherwise.
That is, the pleasure of the first two trances is definitely not feeling of body, because in the state of trance there is no five consciousnesses.
It is also not feeling of mind, because it should be joy.

It is only when the mind is delighted in a stage other than the first two trances, having already been freed from the love of joy, that it can be different from the previous and established as pleasant feeling.
Joy is feeling of joy, and it is unreasonable for two feelings to occur together in one mind.
If you say that there is no such error because joy and pleasure occur alternately, this is also unreasonable, because it is said that the first two trances have five members and the third has four.

If you say that the five and four are spoken of in terms of possibility, and that they do not necessarily occur together, this is not reasonable, because there would be samÄdhi with applied thought but no sustained thought.
However, a scripture says that there are three kinds of samÄdhi, with applied thought and sustained thought, etc.
If the members of dhyÄna do not necessarily occur together, why does the scripture not say that there is samÄdhi with applied thought and no sustained thought?
Also, in the realm of desire and the first trance state, there would be the three samÄdhis.
This would contradict the scriptures.
Now we must consider the question: In the third trance state, the feeling of satisfaction in the mind is called the faculty of joy. Why is it called happiness?
This is called happiness because it has a cause, because the faculty of joy is not tranquil.
This means that joy is agitated and disturbs the mind in samÄdhi, just as waves in water are agitated and move about.
The feeling of satisfaction in the mind in the first two trance states has this characteristic, and therefore it is called joy.
In the third trance state, this mental pleasure and feeling are calm and quiet in their characteristics and are called pleasure.
Therefore, in this trance state, the function of equanimity increases, and because one abandons joy, the member of equanimity is established.
In the fourth trance state, one again abandons pleasure, and therefore the equanimity of this trance state is said to be pure.

Why is it that mindfulness and discernment exist in all the stages, but mindfulness is only in the upper two trance states and discernment is in the third trance state, and only then are they established as members?
Because they assist in accordance with what is appropriate.
Joy and pleasure are the most relished flavors for all sentient beings in the three realms of existence.

In the third trance state, they are relished to the extreme, because there is the most excellent pleasure in birth and death. It is reasonable to establish discernment in order to observe and abandon them.
If one is without discernment, one cannot even perfect the good roots of oneâ€™s own stage, much less progress to seek the superior.

In order to cure the faults of oneâ€™s own stage in this way, the third trance state establishes discernment as a member, but the other stages are not like this and therefore do not establish discernment.
